Typical English golden ale with stable, moussy, irregular, snow white head over a very slightly hazy (but cloudy with deposit), ochre blonde beer with very subtle olive green hue. Unusual and, frankly, not too inviting aroma of biscuit and toasted bread, green olives, cervil soup, melting rubber, grass, buttermilk, crushed weeds, caramelized witloof, candied apricot, bread dough, raw Brussels sprouts, earth, old cake. Taste begins rather neutral (as usual in this style), some subdued fruitiness (cucumber, unripe berries), medium carbonation, grainy sourishness with even a slightly drying effect, somewhat yeasty and starchy but not overly so, rather thin body as expected, mineral water, toasted maltiness appearing quickly but not as much as in many darker coloured beers, bready, all restraining from actual sweetness and managing to do that very well; in the finish, a relieving, leafy and earthy, low hop bitterness appears, lasting quite long, with a bready, in fact almost sourdough-like graininess piercing through it all; this mild but persistent hop bitterness (fortunately) stays with you as the last impression, but remains too subtle to save the day.  I may have stumbled upon an old bottle - clearly this style is intended to be consumed fresh - but I must say, I expected more from this, this is actually quite unbalanced, boring and strange in a not very appealing kind of way...  Even in this style, I find this one of the lesser exampes I tasted so far.

12 ounce bottle

I finally tracked down a bottle of this liquid gold and having tried it understand the fuss. This is truly one of the best low gravity beers in the world hands down. Instead of throwing in lots of hops or a heavy malt bill it succeeds by balancing a soft mouthfeel with rich flavor. I will definitely be buying some to take home.

Aroma / Appearance - The golden body is radiant like a morning sunrise. Accompanying it is a crisp white head the color of bleached clothes. Fruity hops and lemon crisp smell like an open airy white wine. Bright and intense it strikes that perfect balance between "too much" and "not enough."

Flavor / Palate - Lemons and rosy hops sweeten the palate which begs for more. The sweetness turns dry over time until it rests on the back of the throat. A reasonable amount of finish makes it easy to remember the flavor profile without hanging like a cloud of smog. The bitterness is right on the razors edge of perfection. I would love to see some US brewers try to pull this off (like Stone or Against the Grain).

{thoughts} Crisp brew, a fine hope focus without being out of balance, though the aroma was on the timid side.

{elements} Brilliant straw hue; compact, sudsy white head. Soft, biscuity malts and bright apricot hops with a delicate ginger undertone. Lightly sweet, bright acidity, moderate bitterness; clean, fruity and lively. Creamy texture, soft carbonation, light bodied.
 50cl bottle, best before November 2011.

Cask at Charlies.
Clear golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of rass and hops with notes of pine needles.
Fruity flavour of hops and grass with flowery notes and notes of pine needles.
Dry hoppy finish.

Cask at CharliesKBH. Clear golden - white head.
Toasted. Light hoppy. Fruity dryness. Apricot. Grassy. Light bitterness. Tea. Herbal. Light and pleasant.
Gold colour with no head, low in aroma but hight in taste, I got honey, vanilla and some hops.
27th October 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! On tap at the Sun Inn, Kelvedon. Nice citrusy hops in this gold beer. Quite sharp and pleasantly bitter.

Bottle. Golden, very small and very short head.  Light to moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, very fruity, citrus hoppyness and some honey. Body is light to medium, malty and sweetish flavor, very fruity, citrus hoppyness and some honey. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, fruity  some honey. Light bodied and fruity ale  too thin and sweet for me.

500 ml bottle.
Pours a clear golden colour with a small white head. Somewhat lacy. Aroma of pale malts, floral hops and hay. Flavour of similar elements. Medium bodied, slick and dryish mouthfeel. Nothing special, but well done any way.

The Olde Dog Inn at Herongate, Brentwood, Essex.Cask pint. OK, I can see what all the fuss is about. Pours to a quick quietly tight and lasting head, slightly off white and gently clinging as the pint goes down the glass. Not an overwhelming nose but flowers and honey and country lanes after rain are there. Clear yellow straw gold, a dancing colour that just looks pleased with itself. A dry mouth, very refreshing and beguilingly easy to drink. A keen effervescence with a tart finish and just the perfect amount of bitterness for its weight. Fruity hops and honey and flowers are balanced beautifully with the spare bitterness. 

Well, this is not the style of bitter I usually go for, I prefer something a little heavier and more swaggering but I could easily be converted. It would be incredibly easy to drink a ridiculous amount of this fantastic beer!

Pale gold colored body with some micro-floaters in it. Mediumsized, grey-shaded blond top. Nice hop driven aroma;  Lychee, mango and sweet citrus, backed by crisp pale malts. [3270-20100803] Cask sample. Sweet lemon yeast aroma. Clear, bright light yellow body with a quick foamy white head. Smooth yeasty flavour has nice lemon hops. Medium body. Very drinkable, aptly named brew.
(@ GBBF 2010, London, England)
draught @ Coeur de Lion, Bath (08/2010). Pale strawy colour, small white head. Citrusy, malty base, dry mouthfeel. Light and refreshing.

Cask at the Edgar Wallace, London. Pours clear, yellow-gold with a modest white head. Nice, fruity hop aroma, some straw. Lightly sweet with mild honey malt, and more citrus hops. Light to medium in body with fine carbonation. Lingering bitter finish with some light earth. Very good.

@ Coeur de Lion, Bath.  Pale yellow.  Very spicy hop nose with light caramel and almost candied hops.  A sugary sweetness with woody, floral hops on the palate.  Fun stuff - I can see the appeal.  Honeyed malt, too, like hoppy honey.

Cask. Glassy gold with no lacing. Grassy hop aroma. Slight butter. Oily in the palate. Nice hop, very dry in the finish. Almost has a hoppy pils character. Sturdy golden malt with a hopped up finish. Sessionable.

2010-08-03. Crisp yellow body with a small fluffy white head. 3+ Flavour is mild, pale malt base is non-descript, very light hoppy character, muted grass. 6+ Mild pleasant hops in the aroma, light lemon and grass character. 7+ Smooth average to light bodied palate suits it. Very subtle and mild. Nice session brew but a bit mild overall. Cask at GBBF 2010
Cask at GBBF 2010. A golden coloured pour with a small white fluffy head. Hoppy, floral aroma. Tastes hoppy, fruity, slightly sweet and bitter. Overrated IMO. Their Amarillo is sublime however.
Cask at GBBF 10. Gold pour with a white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with a hint of pear and peach. Crisp citrus flavours. Nice, fruity bitter finish.

Bottle: Big white to off-white foamy head, disappears quick.
Color is between clear and hazy golden to light yellow.
Smell is a fresh mix of hops, honey, citrus, lemon, light spices, pineapple, tea, hint of grass and dried herbs.
Taste is fresh and fruity: hint of hops, slight bitter and more sweet towards fruit, light spices and honey.
Turns into a bit more dry bitter ale.
Bit of a strange, dry herbed tea, kind of like aftertaste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottled. Golden coloured beer with a thin, short lasting head. Apple in the nose and the taste. In fact a very fruity beer overall. Lovely pint.
Väldigt lätt ljus ale med mycket humlenärvaro om än snäll sådan. Mycket tropisk frukt men nästa helt utan beska. Fin sommaröl
Bottle. Pale blonde, hazy. Lemon and melon in the slightly perfumed aroma. Thin. Perfumed, just a bit too lemony flavor. Hint of pineapple. Still a well made citrus flavored ale.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2016 Cask @ Blackfriars and bottles from Beers of Europe & Ales by Mail. Lychee & resin aroma, hazy golden yellow peach colour.  Tastes of honey and citrus fruits. Cereal aftertaste. Good one.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of madmitch76. Pours golden with a small white head. Sweet malt, fruit and a little citrus in the nose. Medium body, rather sweet and malty with some honey accents and citrus. Discreetly hoppy finish. 040210

A clear yellow/golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of hopbitters with fruits like citrus. The taste of hopbitters too, dry. There is some fruit and sweetness. The aftertaste is sweet with some bitter.
Bottle 0,55ltr: Golden coloured ale with great thirstquencing abillities, like they used grapefruits and lemons?

A fantastic sessionable ale. Usually on tap at the Queens Head in Chelmsford. A gorgeous golden red colour. Quite hoppy with citrus and floral notes. One classic English bitter. Very smooth and balanced. Not overpowering but a tad flat on the aroma. My favourite local micro-brewery. Always consistent bottle conditioned. Superb session ale. Poured into CAMRA pint glass.
Golden and heavily carbonated. Slightly buttery tasting beer with rich undertones but way too much carbonation.

Bottle. Pours slight hazy golden coloured with a medium sized lasting and lacing egg white head. Dry and hoppy aroma with notes of citrus fruit, grass and flowers. Taste of grainy malt, caramel, fruit and grassy hops. Lovely beer.

Nice delicate floral nose, a cracking pale gold in colour, very inviting.  the palate is spot on , soft & smooth & rounded, & the fruit & hops & zip all in perfect balance.  Terrific refreshing zing of sherbert all the way through, with citrus, & nicely bitter hops.   It manages to deliver great flavour & refreshment, without being too clumsy or crass

(bottled .)Felt like I was drinking a Czech Pils..but with a Golden  Ale heartbeat: Goes down like my gf when shes horney..Dry and hoppy . Biscuty malt , like  Bohemien Pils character. Oranges,lemon and citrusy stuff. . Classy.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2010 Cask @ 3 Judges. Very nice to have come across. High expectations for this one. Light golden colour, white head. Aroma is sweet malty. Flavour has sweet malts, is dry and has some fruits. Overall disappointing, nothing more than a regular golden ale. Definitely worth a rerate!

Rerate. Cask @ 2nd Larbert Beer Festival. Aroma and nose of flowery hops, soft malty, medium bodied. Very balanced. +.4
Cask at GBBF 2009. Pours a pale golden colour with a thin head that soon disperses. Definite citrus notes on tasting, but remains smooth and refreshing. A well made beer that is really refreshing.
@GBBF09. A veil of white foam cover a bright golden ale with a subtle hop tone. A superbly balanced session beer.
Golden appearance, medium carbonation. Frothy white head. Fruity aroma, gummy bears and wine gums. Sweet ginger finish.
Large airy white head golden colour. Smells like sweet lemonade. Tastes hoppy and slightly bitter.

Cask at the Wenlock Arms on 6th June 2009. Pale golden clear ale with delicious blend of floral, grass and citrus fruit hop aromas; bitter kick and long hoppy and fruity finish. Frothy white head. Consistently good everywhere Ive had it. An excellent beer, and moreish.

Bottle. Yellow and clear with a lovely
hopiness. Some bitterness as well with a medium body.Refreshing and pleasant.

(Handpump at Fat Cat, Norwich) Golden with big fluffy white head. citrusy aroma and taste is great, well balanced and refreshing. Fairly hoppy with a good bitter sweet balance. A very nice golden beer.
cask at edwardstone white horse, suffolk. very refreshing and easy drinking. clear and full of flavour with light bitterness. a top brew.

Cask - Fat Cat, Norwich. Clear golden with a bubbly white head leaving a good lacing. Aroma profile is of citrus and a sweet floral tone. Flavours are moderately sweet and again plenty of citrus and floral notes combine to make a well-rounded thirst quencher on a crisp and clean body with light carbonation, though fairly soft. Refreshing and moreish.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2009  At London Drinker 25:

As pale as decently allowable but with a nice white head.

Cascade-like nose of grapefruit and pine needle aromas.

The sweetness just claws it back from the hops, well balanced. Some nice toffee flavours too.

A little thin.

Sweet and refreshing with lovely little fruity hops.

In a bottle:  Though it is filtered it stands up well to the process. A tad sweeter definitely but still very tasty.

Cask at the Queens Head in Chelmsford. Clear, yellow beer calls out for sunshine but provides some of its own. Fruit in the aroma is tangy and zesty but subtle, with a light graininess and light bitterness in the flavor. That zest is what ties it all together. Delicate and refreshing.

Ive been waiting fo a while to try this beer....it was worth it! Had on cask at the pride of spitalfields, barmaid was absolutely lovely! pours a really pale gold....fancy that its called brewers gold and its a golden ale...anyway i kinda thought it might be over rated but man was i wrong. i think the best thing about the beer is the body, carries the hop flavours and bitterness really well, its all passionfruity and citrus goodness with that body....sounds like im talking about my wife but man what a body, it just makes and carries the beer!

Pours incredibly pale, almost yellow/gold pint, white head.  Taste is pleasant, light and crisp strawlike hops, some fruit and citrus but not much impact and a mild bitter finish.  A decent beer, but I was surprised it scores so highly.

[bottle] Hazy, pale golden colour with a short foamy white layer. Spicy and slightly flowery hoppy nose with notes of citrus and a moderately sweet malty background. Bitter flavour, light but not watery body, moderately carbonated and dry mouthfeel. Delicate malty base with a citrus-fruity, piney and slightly spicy hops character. Bone-dry and bitter hoppy and quite 
lasting finish. Aromatic and well-crafted brew [22.XII.08].

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2010 Cask at the Battersea Beer Festival, 12th Feb 2010. Bright gold with lots of fresh, citrus hop aromas and flavours. Great balance and weight
Earlier rate: 6/3/7/3/15. Cask at the Eastbourne Beer Festival, 9th Oct 2008. The Daddy of English Golden Ales, this was not in the form that I remember it in when I first tasted it in Oxford, just after its CBOB win in 2005. Farmyard funk spoils the aroma. Bright clear gold appearance. The balance in the taste is still there and the finish is just long enough but I really need to re-rate this at some point in the future.

Cask at Blackfriars. Golden in colour with a small foamy head. Aroma of citrus hops, peachy and lychee notes. Flavour is clean hoppy grapefruit witha nice balance of fruity hops. Not too overpowering. Fresh and pleasant to session. Good work for a British beer but i would prefer something hoppier
Cask in Prid. e of Spitalfields. Golden colour. Sweet with bitter finish. Good mouthfeel and you could easily sink a few of these.

Pours a rich golden yelow with moderate head. Scents of hops and citric fruits. Flavor is of grapefruit and strong hops. What a treat. Very easy drinking beer with a fantastic taste. Could do for a session. A

From cask at Charlies. Pours clear and golden yellow, bubbly white head. Solid fruity hops aroma. Flavour is sweet and fruity. Light peachy accent from the hops. Quite smooth and easy. Smooth fruity and ligh bitterness in the finish. Nice one.

Hoppy in aroma, hoppy, balanced and refreshing in taste like so many of these beers are.  Absolutely nothing offensive about it at all, each pint I’ve ever had has been entirely drinkable and pleasing.  I can’t seem to find anything about it that is outstanding in anyway.  It’s all there, but just turning up to a final shouldn’t guarantee greatness.  Some nice fruit flavours, it’s clean, it’s bright and it’s drinkable - I guess in a way I’ve answered my own question.  Are these not fairly often the CAMRA guidelines for Champion Beer of Any Festival?
Cask @ Wenlock Arms Clear, light amber, notes of hops, grapefruit, ripe fruit, bitter and bitter finish, good mouthfeel

Tasting notes from 2003 Banbury beer festival.  An excellent golden ale and what a treat.  Golden, clear with white head.  Citrus, caramel, and fresh floral aroma notes.  Citrus (Grapefruit) and balancing caramel notes.  Refreshing bitter finish that invites you to continue the session.
Cask @ Wenlock Arms. Clear golden. Sweet fruity aroma with hoppy and caramel notes. Swert flavor with hoppy, citric and caramel notes. Ends bitter.

Cockney Pub, Aarhus, DK.
Cask/real ale, 130608.
Orange with white head. Hoppy aroma and flavor of malt with fruit notes nicely balanced to the bitterness

Cask at The Pride of Spitalfields. Light stone fruit aroma. Darker gold color with a white head. Medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is like peach with citrus over pale malt. Touch of bitter. Fruit varies from time to time. Finishes softly bitter without wholly losing fruit notes.

Cask @ The Wenlock Arms, London.
Pours handsomely golden with a small, frothy white film head on top. Aroma is softly hoppy with fruitiness and an underlying crispness to it. Fine carbonation, just perfect for the style. Flavour is elegantly composed, rather dry, fine hoppiness and that underlying crispness again. Very good for a 4 % ABV.

Cask, The Tap, Peterborough. Musty hop snout with tinned mandarin. Smooth and efficient. Sparkling gold thinly lidded with white. Grapefruit and orange with vanilla sweet malty afters.Tasty but a bit wishy-washy, and cant really hold its own against the more spikily hopped local brews. Pretty bog standard citrussy golden ale. Good, but overrated.

Cask at the Three-Legged Mare, York. One of best beers around. Lovely aromas of lemon and malt but flavours are outstanding in this beer. I love how the spice and lemon get you at the beginning but the taste is finished off nicely  with a complimenting bitterness. A complex, though well-balanced pint, its definitely worth seeking out and at 4.0%, its the perfect session beer.

Cask at the Three-Legged Mare, York. This is one of the best beers Ive ever had. Its a nice golden colour with a strong floral aroma. Its extremely hoppy and flavourful with lots of citrus fruit. I love any beer that tastes this good while still being relatively low in ABV. Wonderful.

Cask @ Seven Stars, Holborn, London. Nose of hops, lemon, grapefruit and some sulphur. Pours an opaque lemon coloured beer with a light head. Mouthfeel is incredibly soft, taste is hoppy with a bitter grapefruit quality. Nicely balanced a great British beer.

Cask @ 3 Legged Mare. Bright, golden color with a bubbly white head. Spiciy, citric hoppy aroma, bright and perfumey. Malty, citric, mineral flavor with refreshing notes and a lasting finnish. Medium to light palate, lasting and vivid. Bright, refreshing and intense golden ale.

A real education for me, a great English beer. Hopefully Ill find many more. Apparently this isnt on good form, still very good to me. Nice light hoppy and very drinkable. I could drink this in one, very downable. Its now drunk, Ill certainly have more respect for English beer. I thought it was for bearded elbow patch wearing driving glove classic car fuckwits. Not so by this stuff.

cask @ The Eagle and Child, Oxford. Sunny yellow in colour with aromas of lemon rind, white pepper, and pale malt. Zesty and hoppy with notes of citrus and green grass. Tasted blind, I might have suspected a bit of coriander was in there, but that might just be my wacky palate. Any hint of malt that was there in the nose, drops away almost completely in the mouth. Medium bodied with firm (although somewhat subtle) bitterness. Very refreshing, and undoubtedly a quality beer, but I think their Amarillo was much better.

Bottle (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear pale gold with a spare diminishing white head -- looks pretty flat. Really mild aroma of floral and citrus hops. Flavour follows the aroma, its somewhat watery and consists mainly of light floral hops and citrus with an average bitter finish. Average bodied. I guess if you are in a U.K. hop-free wasteland this seems pretty good but it was pretty dull to me.

Shared with Hogtown harry and Blankboy, Harrys bottle.  Medium yellow, small cask like bubbles.  Decent aroma - some mild hops, mild citrus.  Good taste - nice light malt, assertive yet complimenting bitterness.  Really nice golden ale with a bite.  I could drink this all night long...

Bottle (500ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle.  Wan, mostly clear pale gold pour, virtually no head.  Mild aroma, floral almost perfume hops, light sweet grain - soft.  Taste is also floral, but pungently so, more bitterness in the finish, very light grain malt.  Watery body, fairly still, solid astringency - long lightly bitter finish - excellent, if light.
[Cask at Hereford festival 2006]  Many-awarded golden ale, good but maybe not up to my high expectations. Quite light color, floreal aroma (violet), pleasant but not unforgettable in the mouth

Comments: Very citrusy, limey and floral, tart and bitter cask ale of high quality.

Cask at GBBF. Clear golden colour with a brief white foam. Fresh and clean hoparoma of lemon and orange-peels. Clean floral and citric flavour of lemon, resin and oranges. Long bitter finish of grapefruit. Simplistic but very tasty.

Hand pump at the Dove, Broadway Market, Hackney. Yellow to golden body, small head. Lots of hops and citrus flavours, a floral undertone and some malt sweetness. Very well balanced, long finish. It has a nice silky mouth-feel.

Cask (handpump) @ Magpie & Crown, TW8 Brentford, London. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, sweet, moderate hoppy, grapefruit, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration. Very nice balance and very refreshing. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.
Yellow with a lasting white head. Fresh-hop aroma, citrus and pine. Dry with a very distinct hop flavour.

Very pale straw appearance with a thin head. Citrus scent. Smooth and slightly oily on the palate. Lots of citrus hops. Moderately bitter/sweet.
Cask at Seven Star, London. Pours clear golden with a small head. Nose is fruit and hops. Taste is also fruity (grapefruit) and caramel malt. Nice hops in the end. Very nice mouthfeel.
Slightly diisapointing. Transparant golden colour.  Nice hoppy tropical fruit aroma. Taste very dissapointing. Thin, sour aftertaste and lingering biterness. Not a patch on Brewers Gold Extra
Lemon biscuit! I used to be a big fan of this beer, but it doesnt seem to pack the same punch at the moment. It didnt have much condition to it and had a bit of a medicinal flavour.

Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2007).
Very floral sweet bitterness, excellent session bitter. Beautiful to me, but hard to pinpoint why.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 cask @ london drinker 07. I had this one marked with a star as a must-try and I was sorely disappointed! Very pale yellow w/ white head. Nice nose of lemongrass, hops and fruit. Bitter grapefruit, floral perfume and dishsoap in the taste. Honestly, I dont get it. Whats so great?
*Re-Rate - Cask @ The Pride of Spitalfield. You cant even imagine how happy I am that my palate has evolved...A few months ago I slagged this off but,Oh My, how wrong I was...Golden with a lasting white head, left a nice lacing on the glass. Great conditioning at The Pride by the way, I love the way it clouds up when you swirl the glass. Grassy, floral hops with tropical fruits, orange, pineapple and grapefruit in the nose. Again tropical fruits in the taste, almost like a juice blend with orange, banana, pineapple, hops and some malt rounding it off. Last night I drank two pints in halves, each time saying this was my last, and returned tonight, on my way home from the gym, for two more...Well balanced, delicious and only five mins walk from mine...Score!

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Cask conditioned at the Seven Stars, London WC2 January 2007. Golden coloured, with powerful fresh hoppy aroma of citrus fruits. Flavour was driven by hops as well - dry and refreshing with a smooth finish. Extremely drinkable [4.0]. Re-rate at the Three Tuns, Bristol March 2011. Hop character was far less prominent, both in aroma and on the finish. Perhaps this was because several IPAs were tried at the same time [3.4]

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Golden in colour with a fruity hop nose.hoppy bitter grapefuity with a little sour linger on tongue... TK 2 ...Nice fruity bright hop ... soft and fruity ... bitter grapefruit linger.

Mark brewers gold... Golden yellow... Small white head... Dry zezt custardy nose... Fizz...  Dry custsrdy lemon3.3
Cask @ Real Ale Festival, Gallows Bird, Espoo. Wonderful aroma, honey wood and pear. Very pale, medium head. Very fruity, almost like a lambic-feeling to it. Except for the lacking bubbles.

On cask. Old Cannon in BSE. An incredibly smooth and well produced beer but i was little underwhelmed given that this was champion at GBBF06. Soft and fruity and very easy to drink. The condition wasnt optimal but i would be happy to try this again.

cask at 3 legged Mare, York:  So I really thought that this was the brewers extra gold when I saw if at the pub because I didnt know this one existed, just recognised the name from the site and said that I had to try it, and I was not dissappointed at all.  Matter of fact I cant imagine what the extra gold must taste like.  The beer has a lovely floray hop aroma with some papya in the backround.  I could have just enjoyed the aroma all night.  It comes of the pump a translucent golden that looks to be the essence of refreshing with small white cask head that laces wonderfully.  Flavor with wonderfully hoppy and bitter.  The hops start out as bitter and earthy with hints of citrus, but finish floral and citrusy.  Delicious.  medium body.  beautiful golden ale

Gravity, Oxford CAMRA Festival. Attractive light copper with a cap of sticky white head. Bright fruity and citrus aromas with a nice catty smack, (could there be Columbus in here?) light carmel sweetness, soft all around. The flavor has a subtle play between the estery fruitiness, fresh hop flavor, and soft malts, all blended so seamlessly that its impossible to tell where one ends and the others begin. A delicious lingering toastiness in the finish. This is a profoundly good, well-made ale, thoroughly deserving its accolades. An amazing amount of flavor and interest packed into such a work-a-day style. Also a solidly English beer in yeast character.

Half on gravity. Clear golden. Absolutly no head. Light cirtus aroma. The flavour is also fruity - twisted with sweet oranges and orange shells, Traces of sweet malts come through in the aftertaste. Balanced bitterness. A well judged beer (Ipswich Beer Festival 21.09.2006).

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 Aroma is citrus and grassy and peachy and a bit of pale malts giving it a wee kick of sweetness. Taste is similarly complex hoppy, bitter and dry as hell, totally outstanding beer and no suprise to me at all that its in top beer in britian at the moment. REATE: Cask in Blackfriars: Awsome super drinkable, just amazing stuff. Iv never drank 6 1/2 pints as quick as what i did this. RERATE: Well iv had soo much and its just one of the best most drinkable beers ion the world. up from 4.6-5.

Cask at Peterborough Beer Fest 2006.  Clear golden-yellow with a small white head.  Wild flowers, dry hay and straw, honey, lemon.  Very mild bitterness.  Very crisp and refreshing.  I was both pleased and disappointed by this renowned beer.  Not nearly as tasted as I was hopping but by the end of my pint I realized that this was probably the best one-size-fits-all light blond beer I had ever had.  That still means something.  This one is about mass consumption and both Jo Blo and the beer enthusiasts will find something satisfying in it.  If they could mass market this they could turn the Gold into gold.
Cask conditioned. Very good beer with a good hoppy aroma. More subtle than most blond beers and very drinkable in large quantities!

Golden orange in colour with a weak white head. A strong citrusy aroma of grapefruit and orange, hoppy with a biscuity malt undertone. The taste is dry and a very citrusy combination of grapefruit, lemon and orange. The hops and a smooth biscuity malt flavours come through towards the end, making a dry, yet smooth finish. (Cask @ Charters Bar, Peterborough, before the PBF06 opened).
Cask @ The White Horse, Parsons Green, London. Fruity hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity hoppy flavor with hints of citrus and apples. Fruity bitter aftertaste. Refreshing.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2006 [Cask at GBBF] Clear golden. Freshly citric hoppy nose. Medium sweet. Soft and light, somewhat perfumy. Gentle and hoppy with refreshing witbier qualities. Lingering aromatic, bitter finish. An excellent golden ale well worth its consecutive titles at GBBF.

Cask conditioned at GBBF Sat 5th August 2006. After having to queue for this I was impressed. Poured a golden colour, with a fruity aroma, initially I got a real citric burst on first taste. This beer had a nice bitterness and tasted really fresh and hoppy. Really enjoyed this but compared with Lozs (my partner) Pictish Alchemist, I would still go for the latter.
[cask at GBBF 06] Aroma of sweet fruits, tropical i suppose, some citric notes also. light body, dry finish where a little bready malt comes through. A fine session beer.

Cask (Queens Head, Chelmsford). Golden coloured eith a creamy, lacing head; strong, very aromatic hoppy (hop resins also)nose, mixed with a citrousy fruitiness; robust dry bitter flavour, smooth and light bodied; long, lingering dry hoppy finish with a citrousy fruitiness again, giving way an even hoppier aftertaste. WOW ! Extremely well drinkable, rounded, literally golden ale ! A great pleasure.....................

Golden beer with a very dry fruity aroma.  The flavour is smooth and light with a slightly watery floralness.  Overall a nice golden beer.
Cask at Reading Beer Festival 27 Apr 06. Golden colour. Unclear. Hops and tropical fruits in the aroma. Malty and fruity aftertaste.

(Cask at Wenlock Arms, London 20 Apr 2006) Golden yellow colour, with little head. Fruity nose with lots of hop character, sweetish aroma of citrus, mainly grapefruit and lemon (actually rather reminiscent of those yellow odour refreshers you find in toilets). Casked. Golden colour, small bubbly head. Sweetish, almost urineish, aroma of fruits and wheat. Flavour of honey, fruit and flowery hops. Wellbalanced. Flavour is very nice compared to the aroma.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2006 Cask at Seven Stars, London. Golden with creamy head. Good fresh herbal and parfumy hops in the aroma with aromatic maltiness. Strong hop flavor with very good maltiness and some tropical fruits. Finishes bitter-fruity and malty. Tasted much fresher, hoppier and maltier than  previously at Helsinki beer festival 2006 (rated 8/2/6/3/12).

Quite sweet with definite honey in flavour. Sweet citric aroma. Hoppy and quite floral.

Half pint pulled at the Battersea Beer Fest, very lively, a clear light gold with a large bubly white head. A rich aroma with pollen and fruits for me. A good bitterness all the way through, hints of dried apricots. My favourite beer of the festival (though options were limited both nights I went).
A little sweet in aroma, very hoppy too. The foam is very bubbling. In flavor is a little perfume alike but very bitter.

Cask Stillage at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, Oldham 23/03/2002
Golden coloured pale and very fruity. Bitter hop finish.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 Cask at GBBF 05: very refreshing, quite hoppy but dalicate, very fruity and floral, some grass and pine notes, pretty aromatic, great beer for the summer.
Cask. Golden color with a white head. The taste is a smooth and full body. Has a nice hoppy nose and palate. Very nice.
Cask : The Seven Stars, Holborn. An easy drinking light yellow beer with lots of hops and citrus fruit undertones. I got orange and greatfruit. Lovely!

Cask at the Woking Beer Festival. Yellow with modest head. Excellent citrus hop aroma and a bit floral as well. The taste is rather complex with hints of citrus and apples. a champion bitter it is.
A lovely refreshing brew that could possibly convert (UK brewed) lager drinkers to beer.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2007 Missed this at the 2005 GBBF, so was pleased to catch up with it at The Bedford Festival. The aroma was floral hops, but not dominant. Perhaps it was served a bit too cold? Taste for me was dominated by waxy honey with a hint of fruit, followed by a medium bitter, long-lasting finish. 10.7.07 Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Noted a hint of violet on the aroma and a distinct taste of ginger.

Cask at the Kingston Arms, Cambridge: Pours a pale clear golden with a thin, wispy white head.  Aroma has some semi-sweet, lightly toasted caramel notes and floral hoppiness.  Body starts full and flavorful with a nice balance of grassy, earthy hops and sweet malt.  A very smooth, refreshing and drinkable ale.

Huge fresh floral and citrusy hop nose.  Clear golden body with lasting cover of white head that coats the glass.  Fresh clean malt profile showcases floral, grapefruit hop flavour with just a hint of liquorice.  Fair finishing bitterness.  Light, refreshing body with moderately lively carbonation.  Cask at GBBF 2005.
(Cask at Wenlock Arma, London) Clear apple juice body with white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, light caramel.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit.  Watery light-medium body.

Cask @ GBBF 2005: Golden coloured. Clear. White fluffy head. Fruity and sweet aroma with some herbal and hoppy notes. Flavour is hoppy and fruity with some berries and herbal notes. Is bitter and dry in the end. Is fresh and crisp. This is by far not as good as Brewers Gold Extra, but still a very good cask beer .
Clear gold with a small white head. Nice american hop aroma, loads of piney citrus notes. Sweet biscuity start with lychees, grapefruit and lemon in the finish. Brilliantly refreshing.
Cask @ , Cambridge, UK. 28th May 2005Very blonde with a certain burton character. Very hoppy and still clean tasting. Fruity and refreshing. One of the better modern blondes.

Cask at Wenlock Arms, London
This beer was outstanding.  Golden in colour with a distinctive hoppy nose that has lots of citrus fruits.  Drinks really well and at 4% you can have a few without falling over.  The kind of beer you want to just taste and taste.  Finish is hoppy and lasting.
A zippy little beer. Brewrs Gold it is. Refreshing and pale. Drunk in the pub.

Gravity at Banbury Beer Festival. Yellow. Rich, full, citric taste from beginning to end. Enough taste, but not too much. Nice, smooth and oiley mouthfeel. Tangy, crisp, refreshing. Quite splendid Golden beer.

Cask at The Queens Head, Chelmsford.A clear golden beer with a small white head. Mild but nice and fresh fruity and hoppy aroma. Very fresh flavor as well with a good fruity taste and some hoppy hints. Soft mouthfull with buttery tones. A fine English ale.
Cask Conditioned at the Bedford Beer Festival 2004 (Wednesday Session). Lovely fruity & citric beer. Wonderfuly malty & bitter. Hoppy.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2004 Cask at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. This was a very nice, golden coloured, great white head. Aroma is fruity and hoppy. Flavours are hoppy, fruity and dry. Great session beer.

Cask at the Ipswich Beer Festival 2004, gravity dispense. The hops are what its all about with this light and refreshing golden ale. Would benefit from being served at a slightly cooler temperature than was the case at the IBF. Lovely hoppy aroma and flavour, notes of grapefruit and pineapple. Recommended!

Peterborough Festival. Beer of the festival for me - Goldie looking body, fruity citric taste, almost sour grapefruit in its looks and taste, suprisingly balanced palate, great finish of bitterness balancing out the sourness.

Slightly hazy gold with a small bubbly head.  Aromas are dry and floral aromatic hops with some fruit.  Flavours are dry, bitter, spicy and buttery smooth and floral with fruitiness.  Has a grapefruit-like bitterness on the finish.  Very good!
[Cask conditioned] Golden coloured. Nicely hopped and fruity aroma. Quite hoppy and bitter flavour with a lasting dry finish. Tasty.

From the cask. Fruity flavours both sweet and sharp. Very clean and refreshing.
UPDATED: JAN 28, 2005 Cask at the East Anglian Beer Festival.Wow an amazing,exotic,fruit filled explosion of an ale,once I had tried this I could have stuck with it for the entire festival.
Cask conditioned (served by gravity) @ Hants. Bowman, Dundridge. Flowery, citrus hop aroma. Some malt presence but doesnt interfere with the thick resinous luscious hops. Very refreshing and moreish

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2011 Cask conditioned, no sparkler.  Nice floral hoppy aroma.  Attractive golden colour with a soapy head and excellent lacing. This is more like it.  Crisp, clean and fresh with a spicy and flowery (without being too perfumed) aroma. Grapefruit and citrus flavours and a hoppy finish. An inpressive beer from an impressive brewery. Cask, Battersea Beer Festival.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 
Nov, 2003  Cask fresh @ The Wenlock.  I thought Id rated this and didnt pay it that close attention. It was a lovely drop: tasty fragrant grapefruit rush with a gentle sweetness. Probably the best beer of the night. [3.8]
May, 2012 Gravity cask at the English Festival, Riverside Park. Fresh, juicy and hoppy. A spanking good beer. [3.7]
Cask: Wenlock Arms, London. Poured yellow with a thin head. Had a citrusy aroma with hops. It has a hoppy flavor but I noticed a slight soapiness to it. Not bad.

GBBF 2003, tap: Very nice and deserving of that silver medal. Crisp fresh hop nose, pale gold color, very sticky and lacy head. Citrusy flavors from a good mix of sweet malt and a bitter tangy hopiness. Great balance, medium body. Excellent.

GBBF 2003: I would say it's a darn good brew! Nice intense and pleasant hops and grass nose. Golden color with a little whit foamy head. Hoppy - first some edges on the tongue, takes then a while until it ends in a wonderful smooth and silky finish. Just the mouthfeeling itself was great.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2003 Cask. Good solid beer. Lightly aromatic but the proof is in the tasting. Lightly sweet, hoppy and a slightly bitter finish. A well proportioned beer. Not to big on anything. Re-rated I had to revise this upwards. Its just a quality drink, on more often then not at the Wenlock Arms. Clean fruity, hoppy and lovely.
A very pale coloured ale, with  a loose head that soon disperses. Definite citrus notes on tasting, but remains smooth and refreshing. A fine flavour for a 4 percenter.

Cask Conditioned at Banbury Beer Festival. Pale yellowy gold with short lasting head. A real star of the festival, refreshing and hoppy with citrus notes. The cask emptied early showing how popular the beer was. Flowery bouquet an excellent beer.
Sampled cask conditioned at Christian IV, Odense. Fruity nose and aroma. Refreshing. Ok bitterness. Slightly flat finish.

A golden beer with an OK head. It has a fruity typically ale aroma with hints of the cask too. It has the flat feel of cask conditioned beer. The flavor is ale-fruity, slightly tickling and ends of in a good bitterness.
